question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the curriculum standards that North Carolina has for their public schools. I also learned how to think about equitable education. A way of thinking that will stick with me is that you will never have the holistic insight about a school system only based on your experiences. You will never know the resources the lower-income student had, the student with disabilities had, or others with disadvantages without being in their spaces.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Ginny’s course enabled deep self-reflection on classroom experiences and dynamics. Class discussions encouraged me to analyze my personal experiences as a student through a more inclusive, empowering lens. I gained valuable skills, as this course:
(1) Demonstrated the importance of active, ethical community engagement within Durham. I now better understand how to contribute positively.
(2) Explored diverse student identities and the role teachers play in shaping the educational journey. My views on what defines a student transformed.
(3) Emphasized reflective practices for personal growth. I realized that self-critique motivates positive change.
Overall, the open dialogue completely shifted my perspective -- I now approach learning spaces with greater open-mindedness, conscious of how I can promote equity. Without this experience, I may have struggled to fully participate in higher education communities in a thoughtful, constructive manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to have a truly open conversation with people of different backgrounds and how to incorporate all of their experiences into common ground for us to discuss.
2. I really practiced reflecting on my own experiences in the classroom in a concise, thoughtful manner.
3. The teaching skills we gained from experience in the classroom were invaluable. I learned to be mindful of every single student in the room and create welcoming environments for kids.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-engaging in pedagogy

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Ginny facilitated an empowering student-led dialogue -- a welcome change from the typical classroom power dynamic. By positioning us students as discussion leaders, I engaged more actively with the material and my peers' diverse perspectives. This collaborative approach revealed profound insights into lived classroom experiences often overlooked. I felt heard, valued, and motivated to continue finding my voice.
I would urge Ginny to persist in inverting the hierarchical professor-student relationship, as it was incredibly rewarding and exciting. Treating students as equals deserving of intellectual authority promoted more introspection and, therefore, better discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Ginny was an amazing professor, like genuinely one of the best teachers I've ever had. She always let us motivate our group conversations, stepping in when necessary. I loved that we always sat in a circle to discuss and talked freely by calling on each other, instead of being called on by a teacher (which can make conversations feel forced or graded). She was always so understanding and genuinely cared about the wellbeing of all of her students, and was always willing to meet individually just to talk about your day.

course: EDUC-118FS-01 : CRITICAL RACE THEORY IN EDUC.EDUC-118FS-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to view social injustice from a Critical Race Theory lens. There are five tenets of the Critical Race Theory: Race is ordinary not an aberration, differential radicalization, counter-storytelling, and interest convergence. We discussed how these themes are imbedded into education systems.
